questions.text: A patient with a history of severe asthma is involved in a car accident. Emergency medical services arrive promptly and provide initial care at the scene. However, during transport to the hospital, the ambulance is involved in an accident due to the negligence of another driver. As a result of the second accident, the patient sustains a severe head injury and is left with permanent brain damage. The legal and ethical implications regarding liability and causation would need to consider which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Novus actus interveniens

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because he has not yet begun to walk or speak. Assessment of his developmental milestones shows severe intellectual disability. He dies 6 months later from refractory seizures resulting in respiratory failure.  Autopsy shows pallor of the substantia nigra, locus ceruleus, and vagal nucleus dorsalis. The underlying  condition responsible for this patient's death is most likely caused by a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Phenylalanine hydroxylase

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a known history of type 1 diabetes presents to the emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain for the past 24 hours. On examination, he is tachycardic, tachypnoeic, and appears dehydrated. His blood glucose level is 450 mg/dL, and arterial blood gas analysis reveals pH 7.25, pCO2 30 mmHg, and bicarbonate 15 mEq/L. Which of the following tests will be positive in the urine of a patient who has undergone prolonged starvation?
questions.solution: Ans. A) 1 and 3

Temperature is 38 C (100.8 F), pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 16/min. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The lips and fingertips appear blue and the oxygen saturation is 84%. Supplemental oxygen is started but does not improve peripheral oxygen saturation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hypoxemia?

Laboratory evaluation shows increased levels of neutral amino acids in the urine.  This patient's symptoms would most likely respond to which of the following supplements?

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to accidental drug ingestion. His mother states the patient was playing by himself earlier today and 2 hours later she found him unresponsive in the bathroom. There was an empty bottle of hydrocodone-acetaminophen next to him, but she does not know how many pills were in it.  The emergency medical team found the patient stuporous and with bradypnea. His mental status and respirations promptly improved after 1 dose of intravenous naloxone was administered, and he was transported to the hospital. On arrival, the patient is sleepy but arouses easily to voice and follows simple instructions. Vital signs, including respirations, are normal. One hour later, he has worsening lethargy, bradypnea, and miosis. Which of the following most likely accounts for this patient's current clinical deterioration?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Short half-life of naloxone

questions.text: A 1-day-old boy is diagnosed with hyperphenylalaninemia by newborn screening. He is placed on a special phenylalanine-restricted diet with tyrosine supplementation. The parents are extensively counseled on the boy's condition and informed of the necessary dietary restrictions. They are also instructed to return to his physician for regular follow-up visits. Several months later, laboratory test results indicate that the infant has a normal serum phenylalanine level. Careful examination, however, reveals some neurological abnormalities, including axial hypotonia and microcephaly. Further workup is notable for  elevated prolactin, and his physician suspects a cofactor deficiency. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to worsening rash and profuse sweating for the past week. Symptoms began gradually, and the patient first noticed the sweating on a cold day, which he thought was unusual. He has also felt generally unwell, with difficulty sleeping and sensitivity to light. Physical examination shows an anxious-appearing boy with obvious hyperhidrosis. Temperature is 36.7 °C (98.1 °F), blood pressure is 170/96 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 16/min. Skin examination is significant for an erythematous maculopapular rash over the torso, thighs, and upper arms, as well as pink macules over the palms and soles with associated desquamation. Neurologic examination shows a slight tremor. Excessive exposure to which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Mercury

  2. Burn injuries - occur due to flame released during the firing

questions.text: As part of an experiment, healthy volunteers undergo a 12-hour fast and then drink a solution containing radiolabeled alanine. Consecutive blood samples are drawn every 15 minutes for the next 3 hours. Initial blood samples detect the radiolabeled alanine, but analysis of later samples shows that the radiotracer is present in blood primarily in the form of glucose. Before alanine can be converted to glucose, its amino group is transferred to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) α-Ketoglutarate

 

Alanine participates in gluconeogenesis through the alanine–glucose cycle. In the liver, alanine donates its amino group to α-ketoglutarate in a transamination reaction catalyzed by alanine aminotransferase (ALT), forming glutamate and pyruvate. The pyruvate is then converted into glucose via gluconeogenesis, while glutamate enters nitrogen metabolism for urea formation. This transfer allows nitrogen from peripheral tissues to be safely transported to the liver.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. L-citrulline: Incorrect. Citrulline is an intermediate of the urea cycle, not directly involved in transamination. It is formed from ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate during ammonia detoxification.

 

Option C. Malate: Incorrect. Malate is part of the TCA cycle and also serves as an intermediate in the malate–aspartate shuttle, but it does not participate in amino group transfer.

 

Option D. Citrate: Incorrect. Citrate is an intermediate of the TCA cycle that carries acetyl-CoA from mitochondria to the cytosol for fatty acid synthesis. It is not involved in transamination or alanine metabolism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent kidney stones. A urine specimen was collected and subjected to microscopic examination. The results revealed several findings, including the one shown below. Additionally, there were signs of red blood cells and white blood cells in the urine. questions.solution: Ans. D) Cysteine

questions.text: 65-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnoea & pulmonary function testing was done. FEV1 is 2.5 L (78% predicted), FVC is 4.00 L (94% predicted), and the FEV1/FVC ratio is 62.5%. The flow-volume curve is shown. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subglottic stenosis

 

The flow-volume curve shows flattening of both the expiratory and inspiratory limbs, which is characteristic of a fixed upper airway obstruction like subglottic stenosis. This pattern differs from the scooped-out expiratory limb seen in obstructive lung diseases and variable flattening seen in vocal cord paralysis or aspiration.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Aspirated foreign body: Typically causes a focal obstruction, not the fixed pattern seen here.

 

Option B. U/L vocal cord paralysis: Produces variable extrathoracic obstruction, with inspiratory flattening.

 

Option D. COPD: Leads to a concave or "scooped-out" expiratory limb, not the fixed flattening throughout the curve.

questions.text: Identify the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barium meal

 

The image demonstrates a classic barium meal radiograph, with opacification of the stomach and proximal duodenum, outlining the gastric contour and first part of the small intestine. The study is typically performed to assess the stomach and duodenum for ulcers, masses, or other pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BMFT (Barium meal follow-through): Would include more distal small bowel (jejunum/ileum) opacification after barium passes through, not limited to stomach and duodenum.

 

Option C. Barium enteroclysis: Involves direct infusion of barium into the small intestine and demonstrates detailed small bowel loops, which are not seen here.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of fatigue that has progressively worsened over the past month. The patient was recently diagnosed with celiac disease, but she has not strictly adhered to a gluten-free diet. Laboratory evaluation reveals macrocytic anemia with a low folate level but normal vitamin B12 level. Oral folic acid is prescribed. Which of the following biochemical changes is most likely to occur to homocysteine, methionine and MMA respectively, in this patient after starting treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease, increase, no change

 

In folate deficiency, homocysteine accumulates because 5-methyl-THF is required to remethylate homocysteine to methionine (via methionine synthase, B12-dependent).

 

  • After folic acid therapy, remethylation resumes: homocysteine decreases and methionine increases.
  • Methylmalonic acid (MMA) is normal in pure folate deficiency and remains unchanged; MMA rises only in vitamin B12 deficiency (methylmalonyl-CoA mutase).

choices.text: Spine in lateral flexion & extension view

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who is being treated for rheumatoid arthritis, presented with muscle weakness and rigidity in her upper limbs. Which of the given X-ray views should be performed to evaluate her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spine in lateral flexion & extension view

 

  • In rheumatoid arthritis patients with symptoms like muscle weakness and rigidity, the lateral flexion and extension views of the cervical spine are essential for evaluating dynamic instability, particularly at the atlantoaxial joint (C1-C2), which is commonly involved and can lead to subluxation or spinal cord compression.
  • These views help detect any abnormal movement or subluxation that may not be visible on static X-rays.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Open mouth view: Useful to visualize the odontoid process and C1-C2 relationship but does not assess dynamic instability.

 

Option C. Swimmer's view: Best for visualizing the lower cervical and upper thoracic vertebrae when obscured on lateral views, less relevant for RA upper cervical involvement.

 

Option D. Schuller's view: A specialized view for temporal bone imaging, not related to cervical spine evaluation.

questions.text: Which of the following can occur in a patient with prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior quadrantanopia

 

  • Prolactinomas are pituitary tumors which can grow large enough (macroprolactinomas) to compress the optic chiasm, located just above the sella turcica.
  • The optic chiasm anatomy with crossing fibers is organized such that the inferior retinal fibers (which receive superior visual field information) cross in the anterior chiasm.
  • Compression of the inferior fibers in the optic chiasm may result in superior visual field defects, including superior quadrantanopia. This is less common than the classic bitemporal hemianopia but can occur depending on tumor location and chiasmal anatomy.
  • Visual field defects from prolactinomas are usually bitemporal hemianopias but can vary in pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior quadrantanopia:

 

  • Inferior quadrantanopia usually results from lesions further back in the visual pathway, especially the temporal lobe (Meyer's loop) or parietal lobe.
  • It is not a typical finding in prolactinoma because these tumours do not compress these posterior visual pathways.

 

Option C. Priapism:

 

  • Priapism (prolonged painful erection) is not a typical feature associated with prolactinoma.
  • Prolactinomas often cause hypogonadism via prolactin-induced inhibition of gonadotropin-releasing hormone, leading to decreased libido and erectile dysfunction, the opposite effect of priapism.

 

Option D. Failure of lactation:

 

  • Prolactin is the hormone responsible for stimulating milk production.
  • Prolactinomas cause elevated prolactin levels leading to galactorrhoea and sometimes inappropriate lactation or failure of lactation due to disrupted hormonal balance.
  • However, the term "failure of lactation" is usually not associated with prolactinoma; instead, excess prolactin causes milk production outside of pregnancy or lactation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man with depressed mental status is brought to the emergency department by police. Due to fear of arrest, he swallowed a handful of pills as the officers approached him. On examination, the patient responds to painful stimuli but is somnolent. Pupils are <2 mm. Respirations are 6/min. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following changes to temperature, BP and Tidal volume respectively are most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Decrease, decrease, decrease

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents after they found her unresponsive in the basement. They report that her younger sister sprayed the patient with a bottle that had been filled with pesticide to help rid the house of insects. Temperature is 36.6 °C (98 °F), blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, pulse is 58/min, and respirations are 42/ min. On examination, the patient is lethargic and salivating. Which of the following medications should be administered first during treatment of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Atropine

questions.text: Which of the following methods cannot be used to precipitate proteins?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Moving pH away from isoelectric pH

questions.text:

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has undergone lung transplantation. Which of the following etiological agent is responsible in this condition?

questions.text: A healthy 34-year-old coal mine worker is trapped underground following partial collapse of an access shaft. Rescue efforts are directed toward clearing the obstructed tunnel, but it takes 2 days to reach him. While being taken to the surface, the miner tells rescuers that he feels dizzy and weak. He had an emergency supply of water but has not eaten anything for over 30 hours. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 78 mg/dL. Which of the following  biochemical reactions is most likely responsible for maintaining this patient's current blood glucose levels?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Oxaloacetate → phosphoenolpyruvate

questions.text: DNA methylation is not related to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DNA replication

 

DNA methylation is not directly related to DNA replication itself. While replication duplicates the DNA molecule, methylation is a post-replicative modification involving the addition of methyl groups (mainly to cytosine bases at CpG sites) by DNA methyltransferases. This process regulates gene expression and genome stability, but it does not participate in the actual synthesis or unwinding of DNA during replication. Infact DNA is associated with DNA DeMethylation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mismatch repair: DNA methylation plays a role in mismatch repair, especially in prokaryotes. The parental DNA strand is methylated, helping the repair machinery distinguish it from the newly synthesized, unmethylated strand to correct replication errors.

 

Option B. Chromatin remodelling: DNA methylation influences chromatin structure by promoting histone deacetylation and tighter DNA packing, leading to a more condensed (inactive) chromatin configuration.

 

Option D. Gene silencing: DNA methylation at promoter CpG islands leads to gene silencing by preventing transcription factor binding and recruiting repressor complexes, making it a key epigenetic regulatory mechanism.

questions.text: In urea cycle disorders, which of the following can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Phenylbutyrate

questions.text:
Which is the correct sequence of steps in the isolation of desirable protein using recombinant DNA technology?

 

 

  1. Expression of protein and lysis of bacterial cell
  2. Incorporation of genes into bacteria
  3. SDS PAGE
  4. Protein elution
  5. Hybridization
questions.solution: Ans. A) 2, 1, 3, 5, 4

questions.text: A 3-year-old, previously healthy boy is brought to the emergency department due to accidental drug ingestion. His mother found him playing with his grandfather's pill bottles earlier today, and later, he developed nausea and vomited twice. The patient also began breathing rapidly and appeared ill. His grandfather recently had a myocardial infarction and takes multiple medications. On physical examination, the patient is mildly lethargic, tachypneic, and tachycardic. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The extremities are warm and capillary refill time is normal. Laboratory studies reveal high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Treatment with intravenous sodium bicarbonate infusion is begun. This therapy is most likely to provide a beneficial effect via which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increasing excretion of the drug in the urine

choices.text: Remove a carbon group from a molecule
Turn pyruvate into an acetyl group
Attach the acetyl group to a cofactor

questions.text: Pyruvate from glycolysis can go in different directions based on the type of tissue, cell, and if oxygen is present or not. There's a big enzyme complex that guides pyruvate towards aerobic metabolism. This complex does many things, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Substrate level phosphorylation

 

The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDH complex) converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, linking glycolysis with the TCA cycle under aerobic conditions. However, PDH does not carry out substrate-level phosphorylation — it catalyzes oxidative decarboxylation, producing NADH but not directly generating ATP or GTP. Substrate-level phosphorylation occurs in glycolysis (e.g., phosphoglycerate kinase, pyruvate kinase) and the TCA cycle (succinyl-CoA synthetase).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove a carbon group from a molecule: Correct. PDH removes one carbon from pyruvate as CO₂, representing a decarboxylation step.

 

Option C. Turn pyruvate into an acetyl group: Correct. PDH oxidizes pyruvate, forming an acetyl group attached to the enzyme-bound lipoamide.

 

Option D. Attach the acetyl group to a cofactor: Correct. The acetyl group is transferred to coenzyme A (CoA) to form acetyl-CoA, which enters the TCA cycle for further oxidation.

questions.text: A researcher develops 2 functional mRNA sequences composed of CUC and CUU trinucleotide repeats, respectively. He subsequently incubates these mRNAs in a solution containing functional ribosomes and tRNAs charged with the appropriate amino acids. After several hours, it is found that both mRNA sequences produce polypeptide chains containing leucine repeats. This observed finding is due to which of the following genetic principles?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Wobble

questions.text: A farmer was sleeping in the field, and he felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Viper

questions.solution: Ans. B) Sex

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in the perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, the following dark brown rhombic crystals are seen under the microscope. What is the test done?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Florence test
